Hi Cesar,

I think this is possible, but the genome crossover/comparison 
p=
rocedures may take longer be harder to implement. First you will 
have to s=
earch for the same nodes and then see if a connection is 
there or not. It =
is just more compicated. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Cesar G. Mi=
guel" <cesargm@...> wrote:
>
> Hi Petar,
> 
> I'm the guy Carolina mentione=
d as a friend on her message. We're 
aware
> of NEAT's FAQ and some old top=
ics on that matter. But basically our
> point is that if we keep innovation=
 numbers for the entire 
simulation
> we don't really need them!
> 
> While=
 crossing over or measuring genotypes distance all it takes to
> work is al=
igning connections that links the same neurons. It is the
> very same effec=
t when using "universal" innovation numbers, isn't 
it?
> 
> Two or more mu=
tations that results in the same connection genes
> during evolution plays =
the same role? Maybe not. I don't know.
> 
> Cesar

hervenski <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:

lot
> >  of
> >  > =
times before (I've searched the group archive). I've been 
discussing
> >  =
> this with my friend and we don't understand how innovation 
numbers
> >  =
are
> >  > assigned to mutations.
> >  >
> >  > Suppose a mutation links no=
de n to node m. If another mutation
> >  linking
> >  > these nodes occurs =
in the same generation, they are both 
assigned
> >  the
> >  > same innova=
tion number, this part was clear. But what if a 
mutation
> >  > linking th=
e same nodes occurs 100 generations later? Is it 
assigned
> >  > the same =
innovation number or a different one?
> >  >
> >  > I've read Stanley's ori=
ginal C++ code and it seems that the new
> >  > mutation is assigned a new =
innovation number, which makes 
sense to
> >  me,
> >  > because the two ge=
nes are not homologous and tracking homology 
among
> >  > genes is the who=
le point of innovation numbers, right? But 
looking
> >  at
> >  > a Python=
 and a Java implementation, both have a global list of
> >  > mutations and=
 will assign the same innovation number to a 
mutation
> >  > linking the s=
ame nodes. In this case, don't innovation numbers
> >  become
> >  > useles=
s? All we need to know to align genes for reproduction is
> >  which
> >  >=
 nodes are getting linked by a certain mutation. Also we could 
be
> >  > a=
ligning genes that have completely different roles in 
completely
> >  > di=
fferent network architectures. It seems wrong to me.
> >  >
> >  > So does =
anyone know how this should be done and why?
